documents.title: Documentation System (AI + Human)
documents.summary: How we design documentation for both AI agents and humans to consume efficiently.

documents.title: Architecture
documents.summary: Domain-based Rust binaries orchestrated by Windmill. Every binary does one thing, takes JSON, outputs JSON.

documents.title: FatSecret OAuth Setup (One-Time)
documents.summary: Complete the 3-legged OAuth flow once. After this, use `$res:u/admin/fatsecret_oauth` in all scripts.

documents.title: Build & Test (Moon)
documents.summary: Fast, cached build pipeline with intelligent task skipping.

documents.title: Documentation
documents.summary: **Designed for both human and AI consumption.** Each doc links to related docs, making it easy to navigate whether you're a person reading or an AI agent following the thread.

documents.title: Recipe Import Pipeline
documents.summary: Automated recipe import: scrape → enrich with nutrition → store in Tandoor.

documents.title: Food Add Favorite
documents.summary: Add a food to the user's favorites list.

documents.title: Food Brands Get All v2
documents.summary: Retrieve a list of food brands filtered by starting characters and optionally by brand type.

documents.title: Food Categories Get All v2
documents.summary: Retrieve all available food categories from the FatSecret database.

documents.title: Food Delete Favorite
documents.summary: Remove a food from the user's favorites list.

documents.title: Food Entries Get (v1)
documents.summary: Retrieve food diary entries for a user.

documents.title: Food Entry Create
documents.summary: Create a food diary entry for a user.

documents.title: Food Entry Delete
documents.summary: Delete a food diary entry.

documents.title: Food Get v1
documents.summary: Retrieve detailed information for a specific food item by its ID, including complete serving and nutrition data.

documents.title: Food Sub Categories Get All v1
documents.summary: Retrieve all sub-categories for a specific food category.

documents.title: Foods Get Favorites (v1)
documents.summary: Retrieve the user's favorite foods list.

documents.title: Foods Search v1
documents.summary: Search for foods by name with basic food information. This is the original search endpoint with simpler response data.

documents.title: Foods Search v3
documents.summary: Search for foods by name or description with comprehensive nutrition data, allergens, and food attributes.

documents.title: Image Recognition API v1
documents.summary: Optional Add-On feature for detecting foods within images.

documents.title: Natural Language Processing API v1
documents.summary: Optional Add-On feature for parsing natural language food descriptions.

documents.title: Profile Create
documents.summary: Create a profile for a user within your application.

documents.title: Profile Get Auth
documents.summary: Retrieve authentication credentials for an existing user profile.

documents.title: Profile Get Status
documents.summary: Retrieve profile status and settings for a user.

documents.title: Recipe Get by ID v1
documents.summary: Retrieve complete recipe details by recipe ID.

documents.title: Recipe Types Get All v1
documents.summary: Retrieve all available recipe type categories.

documents.title: Recipes Search v2
documents.summary: Search for recipes by name or keyword.

documents.title: FatSecret Platform API - Authentication
documents.summary: The FatSecret Platform API supports multiple authentication methods depending on your use case.

documents.title: FatSecret Platform API - Error Codes
documents.summary: This guide documents error codes returned by the FatSecret Platform API.

documents.title: FatSecret Platform API - Third-Party Libraries
documents.summary: Community-maintained libraries and resources for integrating with the FatSecret Platform API.

documents.title: FatSecret Platform API - Localization
documents.summary: Localization features allow you to filter food data by region and receive responses in different languages.

documents.title: FatSecret Platform API - 3-Legged OAuth
documents.summary: 3-legged OAuth allows your application to access user-specific data on their behalf. This is required for food diaries, weight tracking, and exercise logs.

documents.title: FatSecret Platform API - OAuth 1.0 Guide
documents.summary: OAuth 1.0 authentication requires signing each request with your credentials.

documents.title: FatSecret Platform API - OAuth 2.0 Guide
documents.summary: OAuth 2.0 is the recommended authentication method for the FatSecret Platform API.

documents.title: FatSecret Platform API - Parameters Reference
documents.summary: This guide documents common parameters used across the FatSecret Platform API.

documents.title: FatSecret Platform API - Welcome
documents.summary: The FatSecret Platform API provides programmatic access to FatSecret's food and nutrition database.

documents.title: Implementation Scope: food.brands.get.v2
documents.summary: API endpoint to retrieve a filtered list of food brands from FatSecret. This is a **Premier** scope endpoint used for food brand lookup and autocomplete functionality.

documents.title: Implementation Scope: FatSecret food.categories.get.v2
documents.summary: **Status:** Not Recommended for Implementation **Priority:** P3 (Low) **API Tier:** Premier **Date:** 2025-12-31

documents.title: Cheat sheet
documents.summary: Don't have time to read the docs? Here's a quick cheat sheet to get you started.

documents.title: Commands
documents.summary: The following options are available for all moon commands.

documents.title: action-graph
documents.summary: The `moon action-graph [target]` (or `moon ag`) command will generate and serve a visual graph of all actions and tasks within the workspace, known as the [action graph](/docs/how-it-works/action-grap

documents.title: bin
documents.summary: The `moon bin <tool>` command will return an absolute path to a tool's binary within the toolchain. If a tool has not been configured or installed, this will return a 1 or 2 exit code with no value re

documents.title: check
documents.summary: The `moon check [...projects]` (or `moon c`) command will run *all* [build and test tasks](/docs/concepts/task#types) for one or many projects. This is a convenience command for verifying the current

documents.title: ci
documents.summary: The `moon ci` command is a special command that should be ran in a continuous integration (CI) environment, as it does all the heavy lifting necessary for effectively running tasks.

documents.title: clean
documents.summary: The `moon clean` command will clean the current workspace by deleting stale cache. For the most part, the action pipeline will clean automatically, but this command can be used to reset the workspace

documents.title: completions
documents.summary: The `moon completions` command will generate moon command and argument completions for your current shell. This command will write to stdout, which can then be redirected to a file of your choice.

documents.title: docker
documents.summary: Operations for integrating with Docker and Dockerfiles.

documents.title: docker file
documents.summary: The `moon docker file <project>` command can be used to generate a multi-staged `Dockerfile` for a project, that takes full advantage of Docker's layer caching, and is primarily for production deploys

documents.title: docker prune
documents.summary: The `moon docker prune` command will reduce the overall filesize of the Docker environment by installing production only dependencies for projects that were scaffolded, and removing any applicable ext

documents.title: docker scaffold
documents.summary: The `moon docker scaffold <...projects>` command creates multiple repository skeletons for use within `Dockerfile`s, to effectively take advantage of Docker's layer caching. It utilizes the [project g

documents.title: docker setup
documents.summary: The `moon docker setup` command will efficiently install dependencies for focused projects. This is an all-in-one command for tool and dependency installations, and should replace `npm install` and ot

documents.title: ext
documents.summary: The `moon ext <id>` command will execute an extension (a WASM plugin) that has been configured with the [`extensions`](/docs/config/workspace#extensions) setting in [`.moon/workspace.yml`](/docs/confi

documents.title: generate
documents.summary: The `moon generate <name>` (or `moon g`) command will generate code (files and folders) from a pre-defined template of the same name, using an interactive series of prompts. Templates are located base

documents.title: init
documents.summary: The `moon init` command will initialize moon into a repository and scaffold necessary config files by creating a `.moon` folder.

documents.title: mcp
documents.summary: The `moon mcp` command will start an [MCP](https://modelcontextprotocol.io) server that listens for requests from AI assistants. This allows for agentic workflows in your favorite editor.

documents.title: migrate
documents.summary: Operations for migrating existing projects to moon.

documents.title: migrate from-package-json
documents.summary: Use the `moon migrate from-package-json <project>` sub-command to migrate a project's `package.json` to our [`moon.yml`](/docs/config/project) format. When ran, the following changes are made:

documents.title: migrate from-turborepo
documents.summary: This command has been deprecated, use the [`moon ext migrate-turborepo`](/docs/guides/extensions#migrate-turborepo) command instead.

documents.title: Overview
documents.summary: The following options are available for *all* moon commands.

documents.title: project-graph
documents.summary: The `moon project-graph [id]` (or `moon pg`) command will generate and serve a visual graph of all configured projects as nodes, with dependencies between as edges, and can also output the graph in [G

documents.title: project
documents.summary: The `moon project <name>` (or `moon p`) command will display all available information about a project that has been configured and exists within the graph. If a project does not exist, the program wi

documents.title: query
documents.summary: Query information about moon, its projects, their tasks, the environment, the pipeline, and many other aspects of the workspace.

documents.title: query hash-diff
documents.summary: Use the `moon query hash-diff` sub-command to query the content and source differences between 2 generated hashes. This is extremely useful in debugging task inputs.

documents.title: query hash
documents.summary: Use the `moon query hash` sub-command to inspect the contents and sources of a generated hash, also known as the hash manifest. This is extremely useful in debugging task inputs.

documents.title: query projects
documents.summary: Use the `moon query projects` sub-command to query information about all projects in the project graph. The project list can be filtered by passing a [query statement](/docs/concepts/query-lang) as an

documents.title: query tasks
documents.summary: Use the `moon query tasks` sub-command to query task information for all projects in the project graph. The tasks list can be filtered by passing a [query statement](/docs/concepts/query-lang) as an a

documents.title: query touched-files
documents.summary: Use the `moon query touched-files` sub-command to query for a list of touched files (added, modified, deleted, etc) using the current VCS state. These are the same queries that [`moon ci`](/docs/comma

documents.title: run
documents.summary: The `moon run` (or `moon r`, or `moonx`) command will run one or many [targets](/docs/concepts/target) and all of its dependencies in topological order. Each run will incrementally cache each task, im

documents.title: setup
documents.summary: The `moon setup` command can be used to setup the developer and pipeline environments. It achieves this by downloading and installing all configured tools into the toolchain.

documents.title: sync
documents.summary: Operations for syncing the workspace to a healthy state.

documents.title: sync codeowners
documents.summary: The `moon sync codeowners` command will manually sync code owners, by aggregating all owners from projects, and generating a single `CODEOWNERS` file. Refer to the official [code owners](/docs/guides/

documents.title: sync config-schemas
documents.summary: The `moon sync config-schemas` command will manually generate JSON schemas to `.moon/cache/schemas` for all our different configuration files.

documents.title: sync hooks
documents.summary: The `moon sync hooks` command will manually sync hooks for the configured [VCS](/docs/config/workspace#vcs), by generating and referencing hook scripts from the [`vcs.hooks`](/docs/config/workspace#ho

documents.title: sync projects
documents.summary: The `moon sync projects` command will force sync *all* projects in the workspace to help achieve a [healthy repository state](/docs/faq#what-should-be-considered-the-source-of-truth). This applies the

documents.title: task-graph
documents.summary: The `moon task-graph [target]` (or `moon tg`) command will generate and serve a visual graph of all configured tasks as nodes, with dependencies between as edges, and can also output the graph in [Gra

documents.title: task
documents.summary: The `moon task <target>` (or `moon t`) command will display information about a task that has been configured and exists within a project. If a task does not exist, the program will return with a 1 ex

documents.title: teardown
documents.summary: The `moon teardown` command, as its name infers, will teardown and clean the current environment, opposite the [`setup`](/docs/commands/setup) command. It achieves this by doing the following:

documents.title: templates
documents.summary: The `moon templates` command will list all templates available for [code generation](/docs/commands/generate). This list will include the template title, description, default destination, where it's s

documents.title: toolchain
documents.summary: Manage toolchain plugins.

documents.title: toolchain add
documents.summary: The `moon toolchain add <id> [plugin]` command will add a toolchain to the workspace by injecting a configuration block into `.moon/toolchain.yml`. To do this, the command will download the WASM plugi

documents.title: toolchain info
documents.summary: The `moon toolchain info <id> [plugin]` command will display detailed information about a toolchain, like what files are scanned, what configuration settings are available, and what tier APIs are supp

documents.title: upgrade
documents.summary: The `moon upgrade` command can be used to upgrade your current moon binary (if installed globally) to the latest version.

documents.title: Feature comparison
documents.summary: The following comparisons are *not* an exhaustive list of features, and may be inaccurate or out of date, but represent a good starting point for investigation. If something is not correct, please cre

documents.title: Concepts
documents.summary: moon's able to achieve high performance and blazing speeds by implementing a cache that's powered by

documents.title: Cache
documents.summary: moon's able to achieve high performance and blazing speeds by implementing a cache that's powered by our own unique smart hashing layer. All cache is stored in `.moon/cache`, relative from the workspa

documents.title: File groups
documents.summary: File groups are a mechanism for grouping similar types of files and environment variables within a project using [file glob patterns or literal file paths](/docs/concepts/file-pattern). These groups a

documents.title: File patterns
documents.summary: Globs in moon are [Rust-based globs](https://github.com/olson-sean-k/wax), *not* JavaScript-based. This may result in different or unexpected results. The following guidelines must be met when using g

documents.title: Projects
documents.summary: A project is a library, application, package, binary, tool, etc, that contains source files, test files, assets, resources, and more. A project must exist and be configured within a [workspace](/docs/

documents.title: Query language
documents.summary: moon supports an integrated query language, known as MQL, that can be used to filter and select projects from the project graph, using an SQL-like syntax. MQL is primarily used by [`moon run`](/docs/c

documents.title: Targets
documents.summary: A target is a compound identifier that pairs a [scope](#common-scopes) to a [task](/docs/concepts/task), separated by a `:`, in the format of `scope:task`.

documents.title: Task inheritance
documents.summary: Unlike other task runners that require the same tasks to be repeatedly defined for *every* project, moon uses an inheritance model where tasks can be defined once at the workspace-level, and are then

documents.title: Tasks
documents.summary: Tasks are commands that are ran in the context of a [project](/docs/concepts/project). Underneath the hood, a task is simply a binary or system command that is ran as a child process.

documents.title: Tokens
documents.summary: Tokens are variables and functions that can be used by [`command`](/docs/config/project#command), [`args`](/docs/config/project#args), [`env`](/docs/config/project#env) (>= v1.12), [`inputs`](/docs/co

documents.title: Toolchain
documents.summary: The toolchain is an internal layer for downloading, installing, and managing tools (languages, dependency managers, libraries, and binaries) that are required at runtime. We embrace this approach over

documents.title: Workspace
documents.summary: A workspace is a directory that contains [projects](/docs/concepts/project), manages a [toolchain](/docs/concepts/toolchain), runs [tasks](/docs/concepts/task), and is coupled with a VCS repository. T

documents.title: Config files
documents.summary: The .moon/workspace.yml file configures projects and services in the workspace. This file is

documents.title: moon.{pkl,yml}
documents.summary: The `moon.yml` configuration file *is not required* but can be used to define additional metadata for a project, override inherited tasks, and more at the project-level. When used, this file must exis

documents.title: .moon/tasks\[/\*\*/\*\].{pkl,yml}
documents.summary: The `.moon/tasks.yml` file configures file groups and tasks that are inherited by *every* project in the workspace, while `.moon/tasks/**/*.yml` configures for projects based on their language or type

documents.title: template.{pkl,yml}
documents.summary: The `template.yml` file configures metadata and variables for a template, [used by the generator](/docs/guides/codegen), and must exist at the root of a named template folder.

documents.title: .moon/toolchain.{pkl,yml}
documents.summary: The `.moon/toolchain.yml` file configures the toolchain and the workspace development environment. This file is *optional*.

documents.title: .moon/workspace.{pkl,yml}
documents.summary: The `.moon/workspace.yml` file configures projects and services in the workspace. This file is *required*.

documents.title: Create a project
documents.summary: With a workspace, we can now house one or many projects, with a project being an application, library, or tool. In the end, each project will have its own build layer, personal tasks, and custom confi

documents.title: Create a task
documents.summary: The primary focus of moon is a task runner, and for it to operate in any capacity, it requires tasks to run. In moon, a task is a binary or system command that is ran as a child process within the con

documents.title: Introduction
documents.summary: moonrepo is a productivity platform that aims to eliminate pain points for both developers and companies, by automating tiresome and complex workflows, and improving the overall developer experience.

documents.title: Editors
documents.summary: Enhance your VS Code experience with our integrated moon console! Whether you're a fan of the

documents.title: VS Code extension
documents.summary: Enhance your VS Code experience with our integrated moon console! Whether you're a fan of the command line, or prefer interactive interfaces, our console will be a welcome experience.

documents.title: FAQ
documents.summary: The first incarnation of the name was a misspelling of monorepo (= moonrepo). This is where the domain moonrepo.dev came from, and our official company, moonrepo, Inc.

documents.title: Continuous integration (CI)
documents.summary: All companies and projects rely on continuous integration (CI) to ensure high quality code and to avoid regressions. Because this is such a critical piece of every developer's workflow, we wanted to s

documents.title: Code generation
documents.summary: Code generation provides an easy mechanism for automating common development workflows and file structures. Whether it's scaffolding a new library or application, updating configuration, or standardiz

documents.title: Code owners
documents.summary: Code owners enables companies to define individuals, teams, or groups that are responsible for code in a repository. This is useful in ensuring that pull/merge requests are reviewed and approved by a

documents.title: Debugging a task
documents.summary: Running [tasks](/docs/concepts/task) is the most common way to interact with moon, so what do you do when your task isn't working as expected? Diagnose it of course! Diagnosing the root cause of a bro

documents.title: Docker integration
documents.summary: Using [Docker](https://www.docker.com/) to run your applications? Or build your artifacts? No worries, moon can be utilized with Docker, and supports a robust integration layer.

documents.summary: [Solid](https://www.solidjs.com) (also known as SolidJS) is a JavaScript framework for building interactive web applications. Because of this, Solid is an application or library concern, and not a bui

documents.summary: [SvelteKit](https://kit.svelte.dev) is built on [Svelte](https://svelte.dev), a UI framework that uses a compiler to let you write breathtakingly concise components that do minimal work in the browser

documents.summary: An extension is a WASM plugin that allows you to extend moon with additional functionality, have whitelisted access to the file system, and receive partial information about the current workspace. Ext

documents.summary: Utilizing JavaScript (and TypeScript) in a monorepo can be a daunting task, especially when using Bun (or Node.js), as there are many ways to structure your code and to configure your tools. With this

documents.summary: - [Angular](/docs/guides/examples/angular) - In this guide, you'll learn how to integrate Angular into moon. - [Astro](/docs/guides/examples/astro) - In this guide, you'll learn how to integrate Astro

documents.title: Terminal notifications
documents.summary: moon is able to send operating system desktop notifications for specific events in the action pipeline, on behalf of your terminal application. This is useful for continuous feedback loops and reactin

documents.title: Offline mode
documents.summary: moon assumes that an internet connection is always available, as we download and install tools into the toolchain, resolve versions against upstream manifests, and automatically install dependencies.

documents.title: Open source usage
documents.summary: Although moon was designed for large monorepos, it can also be used for open source projects, especially when coupled with our [built-in continuous integration support](/docs/guides/ci).

documents.title: Pkl configuration
documents.summary: While YAML is our official configuration format, we want to support dynamic formats, and as such, have added support for Pkl. What is Pkl? If you haven't heard of Pkl yet, [Pkl is a programmable confi

documents.title: Task profiling
documents.summary: Troubleshooting slow or unperformant tasks? Profile and diagnose them with ease!

documents.title: Remote caching
documents.summary: Is your CI pipeline running slower than usual? Are you tired of running the same build over and over although nothing has changed? Do you wish to reuse the same local cache across other machines and e

documents.title: Root-level project
documents.summary: Coming from other repositories or task runner, you may be familiar with tasks available at the repository root, in which one-off, organization, maintenance, or process oriented tasks can be ran. moon

documents.title: Rust handbook
documents.summary: Utilizing Rust in a monorepo is a trivial task, thanks to Cargo, and also moon. With this handbook, we'll help guide you through this process.

documents.title: Sharing workspace configuration
documents.summary: For large companies, open source maintainers, and those that love reusability, more often than not you'll want to use the same configuration across all repositories for consistency. This helps reduce

documents.title: VCS hooks
documents.summary: VCS hooks (most popular with [Git](https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Customizing-Git-Git-Hooks)) are a mechanism for running scripts at pre-defined phases in the VCS's lifecycle, most commonly pre-commit

documents.title: WASM plugins

documents.title: How it works
documents.summary: Although moon is currently focusing on the JavaScript ecosystem, our long-term vision is to be a multi-language task runner and monorepo management tool.

documents.title: Action graph
documents.summary: When you run a task on the command line, we generate an action graph to ensure dependencies of tasks have ran before running run the primary task.

documents.summary: Although moon is currently focusing on the JavaScript ecosystem, our long-term vision is to be a multi-language task runner and monorepo management tool. To that end, we've designed our languages to w

documents.title: Task graph

documents.title: Install moon
documents.summary: The following guide can be used to install moon and integrate it into an existing repository (with or without incremental adoption), or to a fresh repository.

documents.summary: Now that we've talked about the workspace, projects, tasks, and more, we must talk about something important... Should you embrace moon tasks? Or keep using language/ecosystem specific scripts? Or bot

documents.title: Run a task

documents.title: Setup toolchain
documents.summary: One of moon's most powerful features is the toolchain, which automatically manages, downloads, and installs Node.js and other languages behind the scenes using proto. It also enables advanced function

documents.title: Setup workspace
documents.summary: Once moon has been installed, we must setup the workspace, which is denoted by the `.moon` folder — this is known as the workspace root. The workspace is in charge of:

documents.title: Terminology
documents.summary: | Term | Description | |------|-------------| | Action | A node within the dependency graph that gets executed by the action pipeline. | | Action pipeline | Executes actions from our dependency graph

documents.summary: https://moonrepo.dev/docs

documents.title: Contribute
documents.summary: If you like this application and want it to give back, there are many ways to contribute.

documents.title: Documentation
documents.summary: The documentation is built from the markdown files in the [docs](https://github.com/vabene1111/recipes/tree/develop/docs) folder of the GitHub repository.

documents.title: Guidelines
documents.summary: If you want to contribute bug fixes or small tweaks then your pull requests are always welcome!

documents.summary: !!! info "Development Setup" The dev setup is a little messy as this application combines the best (at least in my opinion) of both Django and Vue.js.

documents.title: Pycharm
documents.summary: PyCharm can be configured to format and lint on save. Doing so requires some manual configuration as outlined below.

documents.title: Related
documents.summary: While not directly related to Tandoor, we make extensive use of the brilliant [recipe-scrapers](https://github.com/hhursev/recipe-scrapers) package by hhursev.

documents.title: Translations
